article:
Rishi Sunak

Rishi Sunak is a British politician serving as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom since 25 October 2022. He was previously the Chancellor of the Exchequer from 13 February 2020 to 5 July 2022. Sunak is a member of the Conservative Party and has been a Member of Parliament (MP) for Richmond (Yorks) since 7 May 2015.

Early life and education (1980–2001)

Rishi Sunak was born on 12 May 1980 in Southampton, Hampshire, to Yashvir and Usha Sunak. His parents were both British Indians who emigrated from East Africa. Sunak's father was a general practitioner, and his mother was a pharmacist. He has two younger siblings, Raakhi and Sanjay. Sunak was educated at Winchester College, a private boarding school in Hampshire. He then attended Stanford University in California, where he studied for a Bachelor of Science degree in economics and philosophy. Sunak graduated with honors in 2001.

Career

Business career (2001–2015)

After graduating from Stanford, Sunak moved to London and joined the investment bank Goldman Sachs in 2001. He worked in the bank's corporate equity division and became a senior banker. In 2006, Sunak joined The Children's Investment Fund Management (TCI), a hedge fund, as a partner. He worked at TCI for nine years and became a prominent figure in the City of London.

Backbencher (2015–2018)

Sunak was first elected as the Member of Parliament for Richmond (Yorks) in the 2015 general election. He was a backbencher and served on various committees, including the Treasury Select Committee. In 2017, Sunak was appointed as the Chair of the Public Administration and Constitutional Affairs Committee.

Local government under-secretary (2018–2019)

In 2018, Sunak was appointed as the Local Government Minister, a position that made him the under-secretary of state for local government. He served in this role for a year and was responsible for implementing various policies related to local government.

Chief secretary to the Treasury (2019–2020)

In 2019, Sunak was appointed as the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, a position that made him the deputy to the Chancellor of the Exchequer. He served in this role for a year and was responsible for implementing various policies related to taxation and public spending.

Chancellor of the Exchequer (2020–2022)

Sunak became the Chancellor of the Exchequer in February 2020, following the resignation of Sajid Javid. He was the youngest Chancellor in over 200 years. Sunak played a key role in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic and implemented various policies to mitigate its economic impact.

COVID-19 pandemic

During the COVID-19 pandemic, Sunak implemented various policies to support businesses and individuals affected by the pandemic. He introduced the furlough scheme, which allowed businesses to claim up to 80% of their employees' wages. He also introduced the Eat Out to Help Out scheme, which offered discounts to customers at restaurants and pubs.

Furlough scheme

The furlough scheme was a key policy introduced by Sunak to support businesses affected by the pandemic. The scheme allowed businesses to claim up to 80% of their employees' wages, with the government paying 80% of the wages and the business paying the remaining 20%. The scheme was introduced in March 2020 and was later extended several times.

Eat Out to Help Out

The Eat Out to Help Out scheme was a policy introduced by Sunak to support the hospitality industry. The scheme offered discounts to customers at restaurants and pubs, with the government paying 50% of the bill. The scheme was introduced in August 2020 and was later extended.

Cost of living crisis and energy crisis

In 2022, Sunak faced criticism for his handling of the cost of living crisis and energy crisis. He implemented various policies to support households affected by the crisis, including a price cap on energy bills.

Budgets

Sunak presented several budgets during his time as Chancellor, including the 2020 Budget, the 2021 Budget, and the 2022 Budget. His budgets focused on responding to the COVID-19 pandemic and implementing various policies to support businesses and individuals.

Other actions

Sunak also took various other actions during his time as Chancellor, including:

* Introducing a new tax on banks
* Increasing the National Living Wage
* Introducing a new policy to support small businesses
* Implementing various policies to support the arts and culture sector

Resignation

Sunak resigned as Chancellor in July 2022, following a dispute with the Prime Minister, Boris Johnson. He was succeeded by Nadhim Zahawi.

Conservative leadership bids

Sunak has been involved in two Conservative Party leadership bids, in 2022 and 2023. He was the front-runner in both bids, but ultimately lost to Liz Truss and Rishi Sunak's own bid.

Premiership (2022–2024)

Sunak became the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom in October 2022, following the resignation of Liz Truss. He was the first British Asian Prime Minister.

Cabinet

Sunak's cabinet included various prominent Conservative politicians, including:

* Dominic Raab: Deputy Prime Minister
* Suella Braverman: Home Secretary
* Grant Shapps: Transport Secretary
* James Cleverly: Foreign Secretary
* Therese Coffey: Work and Pensions Secretary
* Alister Jack: Secretary of State for Scotland

Reshuffles

Sunak reshuffled his cabinet in 2023, replacing several ministers with new faces.

Foreign policy

Sunak's foreign policy focused on various issues, including:

* Immigration: Sunak implemented various policies to restrict immigration, including a new points-based system.
* Russia and Ukraine: Sunak supported Ukraine in its conflict with Russia and imposed sanctions on Russia.
* Israel and Palestine: Sunak maintained a balanced approach to the conflict, supporting both sides.

Local election results

Sunak's Conservative Party performed well in local elections held in 2023, winning several key seats.

2024 general election and resignation

Sunak's Conservative Party lost the 2024 general election, and he resigned as Prime Minister. He was succeeded by Keir Starmer.

Post-premiership (2024–present)

Sunak has become the Leader of the Opposition, a position that makes him the leader of the Conservative Party in opposition.

Leader of the Opposition (2024–present)

As Leader of the Opposition, Sunak will lead the Conservative Party in opposition to the Labour Party government.

Political positions

Sunak's political positions include:

* Fiscal conservatism: Sunak is a strong believer in fiscal conservatism, advocating for lower taxes and reduced public spending.
* Economic liberalism: Sunak supports economic liberalism, advocating for free markets and reduced government intervention.
* Social conservatism: Sunak is a social conservative, advocating for traditional values and social norms.

Public image

Sunak has a public image as a strong and confident leader, who is widely respected across the UK.

Personal life

Sunak is married to Akshata Murty, an Indian businesswoman. They have two children together.

article:
**James Webb Space Telescope**

The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is a space observatory that was launched on December 25, 2021, by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) and its partners, the European Space Agency (ESA) and the Canadian Space Agency (CSA). The telescope is named after James E. Webb, who served as the administrator of NASA from 1961 to 1968. JWST is designed to be the successor to the Hubble Space Telescope and will provide scientists with a new tool for studying the universe in infrared light.

**Features**

### Location and Orbit

The James Webb Space Telescope will orbit the Sun at a distance of approximately 1.5 million kilometers (930,000 miles), which is about four times farther away from Earth than the Moon. This unique location will allow JWST to observe the universe in infrared light, which is invisible to the human eye. The telescope will also be able to observe objects that are too distant or too faint to be detected by other telescopes.

### Sunshield Protection

One of the key features of the James Webb Space Telescope is its massive sunshield, which is designed to protect the telescope's instruments from the heat generated by the Sun. The sunshield is made up of five layers of thin, reflective material that are designed to reflect the Sun's rays and keep the telescope's instruments at a temperature of around -240°C (-400°F). This is necessary to prevent the instruments from overheating and to ensure that the telescope can operate efficiently.

### Optics

The James Webb Space Telescope has a 6.5-meter (21.3-foot) primary mirror that is made up of 18 hexagonal segments. The mirror is designed to collect and focus infrared light from distant objects in the universe. The telescope also has a secondary mirror that is used to focus the light onto the instruments.

### Scientific Instruments

The James Webb Space Telescope has four main scientific instruments:

* **NIRSpec**: This is a near-infrared spectrograph that is designed to study the composition of distant galaxies and stars.
* **NIRCam**: This is a near-infrared camera that is designed to study the formation of the first galaxies in the universe.
* **MIRI**: This is a mid-infrared instrument that is designed to study the formation of stars and planetary systems.
* **FGS/NIRISS**: This is a fine guidance sensor and near-infrared imager that is designed to study the formation of the first galaxies in the universe.

### Spacecraft Bus

The James Webb Space Telescope is mounted on a spacecraft bus that is designed to support the telescope's instruments and keep them at a stable temperature. The spacecraft bus is powered by solar panels and has a communication system that allows it to transmit data back to Earth.

### Servicing

The James Webb Space Telescope is designed to be serviced by a robotic arm that is mounted on the spacecraft bus. The arm is used to deploy the telescope's sunshield and instruments, and to perform routine maintenance tasks.

### Software

The James Webb Space Telescope has a sophisticated software system that is designed to control the telescope's instruments and operate the spacecraft bus. The software system is designed to be highly reliable and fault-tolerant, and to allow the telescope to operate autonomously for extended periods of time.

**Comparison with other telescopes**

The James Webb Space Telescope is designed to be a successor to the Hubble Space Telescope, but it has several key differences. The JWST has a larger primary mirror and is designed to operate in the infrared spectrum, while the Hubble Space Telescope operates in the visible and ultraviolet spectrum. The JWST is also designed to study the formation of the first galaxies in the universe, while the Hubble Space Telescope is designed to study the formation of stars and galaxies in the nearby universe.

**Development history**

### Background (development to 2003)

The idea of building a space telescope that could study the universe in infrared light was first proposed in the 1990s. In 1996, NASA and the ESA signed a memorandum of understanding to develop a joint space telescope that would be capable of observing the universe in infrared light. The project was initially called the Next Generation Space Telescope (NGST), but it was later renamed the James Webb Space Telescope in 2002.

### Early development and replanning (2003–2007)

The James Webb Space Telescope project was officially launched in 2003, with a budget of $3.5 billion and a planned launch date of 2011. However, the project encountered several delays and cost overruns, and it was eventually replanned to include a new spacecraft bus and a more complex sunshield. The project also faced significant technical challenges, including the development of a new primary mirror and the integration of the telescope's instruments.

### Detailed design and construction (2007–2021)

The James Webb Space Telescope project entered a detailed design and construction phase in 2007, with a new team of engineers and scientists. The project was divided into several key milestones, including the development of the primary mirror, the integration of the telescope's instruments, and the testing of the spacecraft bus. The project also faced several challenges, including the development of a new sunshield and the integration of the telescope's robotic arm.

### Cost and schedule issues

The James Webb Space Telescope project has faced significant cost and schedule issues, including a $1.5 billion increase in the project's budget and a delay of several years. The project's original budget was $3.5 billion, but it was eventually increased to $8.7 billion. The project's original launch date was 2011, but it was eventually delayed to 2021.

### Partnership

The James Webb Space Telescope project is a partnership between NASA, the ESA, and the CSA. The project is managed by NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center, with the assistance of the ESA and the CSA.

### Naming concerns

The James Webb Space Telescope was originally going to be called the Next Generation Space Telescope (NGST), but it was later renamed in honor of James E. Webb, who served as the administrator of NASA from 1961 to 1968.

**Mission goals**

### Orbit design

The James Webb Space Telescope will orbit the Sun at a distance of approximately 1.5 million kilometers (930,000 miles), which is about four times farther away from Earth than the Moon. This unique location will allow JWST to observe the universe in infrared light, which is invisible to the human eye.

### Infrared astronomy

The James Webb Space Telescope is designed to study the universe in infrared light, which is invisible to the human eye. The telescope will be able to observe objects that are too distant or too faint to be detected by other telescopes.

**Ground support and operations**

### Micrometeoroid strike

The James Webb Space Telescope is designed to withstand micrometeoroid strikes, which can damage the telescope's instruments and spacecraft bus. The telescope has a shielding system that is designed to protect it from micrometeoroid strikes.

**From launch through commissioning**

### Launch

The James Webb Space Telescope was launched on December 25, 2021, by an Ariane 5 rocket from the Guiana Space Centre.

### Transit and structural deployment

The telescope traveled through space for about six months before it reached its final location. During this time, the telescope's sunshield and instruments were deployed, and the telescope's primary mirror was unfolded.

### Commissioning and testing

The James Webb Space Telescope began its commissioning and testing phase in June 2022. During this phase, the telescope's instruments and systems were tested and calibrated to ensure that they are functioning properly.

**Allocation of observation time**

### Early Release Science program

The James Webb Space Telescope has an Early Release Science (ERS) program that is designed to provide scientists with early access to the telescope's data. The ERS program is a competitive process that allows scientists to propose and conduct observations on the telescope.

### General Observer Program

The James Webb Space Telescope has a General Observer Program that is designed to provide scientists with access to the telescope's data on a first-come, first-served basis. The program is open to all scientists who meet the telescope's eligibility requirements.

**Scientific results**

### First full-color images

The James Webb Space Telescope released its first full-color images in July 2022, which were of the galaxy SMACS 0723. The images were taken in infrared light and show the galaxy in unprecedented detail.

### Bright early galaxies

The James Webb Space Telescope has detected several bright early galaxies that are thought to have formed in the early universe. The galaxies are so distant that they are seen as they appeared when the universe was just 300 million years old.

### Subsequent noteworthy observations and interpretations

The James Webb Space Telescope has made several subsequent noteworthy observations and interpretations, including the detection of water vapor in the atmosphere of a distant exoplanet and the observation of the most distant galaxy ever seen.
